lines.text:
[offering his hand]
Mr. Chaplin! I am a great admirer of yours.
I'm sorry, I prefer not to shake hands with Nazis.

[laughs nervously]
What have you got against us, Mr. Chaplin, hm?
What have you got against everybody else?
Syd, I love this country. I owe it everything. That's why I *can* make fun of it!
The tramp can't talk. The minute he talks, he's dead.
[after telling an obviously made-up story of how he created the Little Tramp characters]
That's bullshit, and you know it.
But the truth is so boring, George!
[Chaplin tells Sennett he intends to leave Sennett's employ and open his own studio]

Charlie, I've been so rotten to you. I don't know if you can forgive me. I forced you to leave Butte, Montana. I made you accept a hundred and fifty per. You mentioned directing and I stuffed that down your throat too. Now tell me how else Uncle Mack can make it up to you!
I want to run my own show, Mack.
Don't kid yourself, Chaplin. You're not that big.
[spits on the floor, missing the spitoon]
That's the first time I've ever seen you miss, Mack.
If you want to understand me, watch my movies.
Charles, you're a foreigner; you're still an outsider. You've never understood this country.
It's a good country underneath, Doug.
No, it's a good country on *top*. Underneath, that's what starts showing when we're scared.

[noticing a pretty girl at the opposite side of a restaurant aisle]
Excuse me Miss, do you always eat alone?
Only when I'm trying to make a new acquaintance. Actually I'm waiting for my girlfriend.
Actually I'm a motion picture director, and I'm forming a new company with Bronco Billy over there.
And you're looking for a new leading lady. Lucky me.
Obviously you are an actress, Miss...
Purviance. Sorry, just a secretary.
Don't be sorry. I'm auditioning for actresses who aren't actresses.
Well, if you're on the lookout for untalented actresses who aren't actresses, then you couldn't do better than me.
[correcting]
Worse than me.

[getting up after being called over by Sydney]
Don't you want to know who I am?
I've no interest whatsoever in who you are
[pauses, Chaplin starts moving away]
Mr. Chaplin.
My Charlie, you weren't even thirty. You was the most famous man in the world, with your own studio, named after you. Couldn't you just enjoy it?
I can now, but couldn't then. It meant too much.

[on the train; remembering Charlie's early days in the theatre]
You took a tail suit out of the wardrobe, tryin' to be a gent. Trying to impress that young dancer... Hetty, wasn't that 'er name?
Hetty Kelly.
Yeah, I could see in your eyes you fancied her.
[chuckles to himself]
Hmm. Sad.
Yes, I know all about it, Fred. She got married. Sent me a lovely note. I brought it with me; it's in my baggage.

[looking worried]
Oh, Charlie, Charlie. Charlie, don't you know? Has nobody told you? She's gone. The flu epidemic after the war carried her away.
[Charlie reels, unable to speak]
I thought someone must have told you, must have written. Didn't nobody?
[Charlie leaves the compartment and goes into the corridor, leaning against the wall and trying to collect himself]

[following him and fixing his tie]
What do we do, Charlie?

[sadly]
Smile.
[they exit the train and are immediately swarmed by a crowd of fans]
Did you lose your other wives this way?
I think so. But you'd have to ask them.
[about Hetty Kelly]
But you didn't even kiss her!
Don't you think I know that?
Nobody wants to see a movie about Adolf fucking Hitler.

[shouts]
I do!
[with one hand throws a chair down the aisle, again fiercely shouts]
I do!

[leaving a screening of one of his movies during the Depression, Chaplin and his wife are surrounded by homeless people. They ask for his autograph and he obliges them. As they leave, he sighes]
I wish they'd asked me for my money.

[Charlie is playing the violin]
Alright Sonny boy, tell your poor little brother today's problem.
Same as the day before, and the day before that and the day before that.
And the day before that, and the day before that.

Alright you're so creative, you work it out! The tramp buys a flower from the girl, in order for the plot to work, she has to think he's rich. That's all, except if you're aware of it, the flower girl is blind. I don't know how to make the girl mistake the tramp for a millionaire.
That's not what dogged me, George. It wasn't that.

It was... it was the knowledge that if you did what I did for a living-if you were a clown-and you had a passion to tell a particular kind of story... something... beyond... but you only had the one chance to get it right. And I never did.

One never does, but, uh, you know that. That's not... the problem. It's when you feel you're getting really close... but you can't make it the rest of the way. You're not good enough. You're not complete enough. And despite all your fantasies you're second rate.
Charlie.
Human. That's very hard.
Say, are you two still married or what? I find it all very confusing.
Mmm... it's not at all confusing. You see, when everyone thought we were having an affair, we were married. Now that everyone realizes we're married, we're getting divorced.
Man's a wizard with women. No question about it.
Nothing quite like it. The feeling of film.

I sometimes wonder if you people realize the responsibility you carry. To my way of thinking, motion pictures are potentially the most influential form of communication ever invented. And there's no control over them. Your message reaches everyone, everywhere.
Message?
Of course. Mr. Chaplin here reaches millions who only have to see. And when they see a mockery being made of our immigration services, I'd call that a message.

Yes, well, as you've already said, Mr. Hoover, motion pictures are for the people. Most of the people work for a living, and they don't make much money doing it. It gives them pleasure to see officialdom and the upper classes getting a kick up the backside. Always has, and it always will. And if that can change things, so much the better.
[to Mary Pickford, in a better pronounced, less cockney voice]
Bet-ter.
He's improving.

[after watching newsreel footage of Adolf Hitler to study Hitler's mannerisms and patterns of speech, in preparation for "The Great Dictator"]
I know you... you bastard!
[Sennett is explaining the film industry to Chaplin as Rollie edits a film]

Now I know this is all new to ya, but remember something, we're all new. This is not an ancient industry. This whole place here is built around speed. Start the story, start the chase. I get bored easy.
How much you reckon Mack? Couple yards of Mabel?
Hmm, yeah. Nah, make it three. But don't go thinking we sacrifice quality. I never make more than two motion pictures a week, but I'll spend up to a thousand dollars on each of 'em if I have to.
Actress?
[first lines]
Ha ha ha ha ha. Come on Charlie stop messing about, we really have to get down to it now. I just hope our friendship survives the day, that's all.
Ha George, don't be so melodramatic.

Well, it's your autobiography Charlie. And as your editor I have to tell you that parts of the manuscript are pretty vague, to say the least. I mean for instance, your mother. Now when did she first lose control? We need to know those facts.
It's hard to say. She could be so wonderful, on good days...
Give us your poor, your huddled masses... Now we have to stop this before it goes too far. Our conception of America does not include, was never meant to include, this kind of scum.
Charlie, you got your pants on back-to-front.
Jesus!
You told him to change, right?
What is he putting on? A suit of armor?
You know what?
hum?
I've always had that gift.
After a man makes love to me, he just goes wild from happiness.
I am happy.
Then tell me when you get sad, because I don't want to be around.
[Chaplin enters a London pub. Immediately, he is recognised]
Well! Here's someone who's had a good war!
Yeah, didn't see him in the bleedin' army!
Come to stare at the animals, Charlie?
Oh, go and sit down, Ted, and give your mouth a rest!
I just came in for a quiet drink. Here, have one on me.
You have one on me, Mr. Charlie fucking Chaplin!
[he throws his drink at him, Chaplin dodges it]
